content.text: Explain the differences between the quantities distance and displacement
State Newton's first law
By reference to the forces acting on the tanker, explain how the tanker may be described as being in equilibrium
1. Complete Fig. 1.2 to draw a vector triangle for the forces \(R\) , \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\)
Use your vector triangle in Fig. 1.2 to determine the magnitude of \(T_{1}\) and of \(T_{2}\)
Two tugs pull a tanker at constant velocity in the direction XY, as represented in Fig. 1.1

Tug 1 pulls the tanker with a force \(T_{1}\) at \(25.0^{\circ}\) to XY. Tug 2 pulls the tanker with a force of \(T_{2}\) at \(15.0^{\circ}\) to XY. The resultant force \(R\) due to the two tugs is \(25.0 \times 10^{3} \text{N}\) in the direction XY
Show that the component of the weight of the log acting down the slope is \(1070 \text{N}\)
Calculate the tension in the cable
tension = .........N
The log is initially at rest at point S. It is pulled through a distance of \(10.0 \text{m}\) to point P
Calculate, for the log,
1. the time taken to move from S to P,
2. the magnitude of the velocity at P
The log starts from rest. A constant frictional force of \(525 \text{N}\) acts on the log. The log accelerates up the slope at \(0.130 \text{m s}^{-2}\)

The cable breaks when the log reaches point P. On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the log. The graph should show \(v\) from the start at S until the log returns to S
Fig. 2.2
A motor drags a log of mass \(452 \mathrm{~kg}\) up a slope by means of a cable, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The slope is inclined at \(14.0^{\circ}\) to the horizontal
Show that the pressure \(P\) due to a liquid of density \(\rho\) is proportional to the depth \(h\) below the surface of the liquid

The pressure of the air at the top of a mountain is less than that at the foot of the mountain. Explain why the difference in air pressure is not proportional to the difference in height as suggested by the relationship in (a)
Define electric field strength
the electric field strength between the plates,
the work done on P by the electric field,
the gain in gravitational potential energy of P,
the gain in kinetic energy of P,
gain in kinetic energy = .........J
the speed of P when it reaches the top plate
A uniform electric field is produced by applying a potential difference of \(1200\mathrm{V}\) across two parallel metal plates in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 4.1

The separation of the plates is \(14 \text{mm}\). A particle P with charge \(3.2 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\) and mass \(6.6 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\) starts from rest at the lower plate and is moved vertically to the top plate by the electric field
Calculate
State Kirchhoff's first law
Kirchhoff's first law is linked to the conservation of a certain quantity. State this quantity
Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the circuit to determine the resistance \(R\)
Calculate the total power generated by G
Calculate the power loss in the total resistance of the circuit
The circuit is used to supply energy to the battery from the generator. Determine the efficiency of the circuit
efficiency = .........
A variable resistor of resistance \(R\) is used to control the current in a circuit, as shown in Fig. 5.1
The generator G has e.m.f. 20V and internal resistance \(0.50 \Omega\). The battery has e.m.f. 12V and internal resistance \(0.10 \Omega\). The current in the circuit is 2.0A
diffraction,
coherence,
superposition
Monochromatic light is diffracted by a diffraction grating. By reference to this, explain what is meant by
A parallel beam of red light of wavelength \(630\mathrm{nm}\) is incident normally on a diffraction grating of 450 lines per millimetre
Calculate the number of diffraction orders produced
number of orders = .........
The red light in **(b)** is replaced with blue light. State and explain the effect on the diffraction pattern
the absorption properties of the radiation,
the effects of a magnetic field on the radiation
A radioactive source emits \(\alpha\) -radiation and \(\gamma\) -radiation
Explain how it may be shown that the source does not emit \(\beta\) -radiation using
